ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was introduced to the various neuroscience/psych research methods and approaches. We learned about research study design, brain anatomy, and neuroimaging methods. Weekly reaction papers helped us analyze and critique previous research papers. We created our own Implicit Associations Test and collected data from the psych pool. We also wrote our own research proposals.

Juast like the title said, learned about possible research Methods in Neuroscience and applied one in final paper, which helped me familiarize myself deeply with the practice of writing a scientific paper and designing a psychological experiment. Also learned to criticize papers.
Scientific reading and writing, fMRI methods, and how to conduct literature reviews and searches.
I learnt a huge amount about the structure of the brain, neuroscience methods, and scientific writing
I learned a lot about scientific writing and research methods. Some highlights include learning about fMRI and brain anatomy.
Building sheep brain, learning about interesting neuroscience lab techniques, learning to write

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Stephanie Lazzaro is one of the kindest and most passionate professors Ive had the pleasure of having at Yale. She cares deeply about her students wellbeing and ability to learn. She welcomes discussion during class and lectures in a very engaging manner. She is readily available to meet with students and is very organized (posts powerpoints and assignments on Canvas, returns grades with feedback quickly, etc).
Weaknesses: None

Overall this course was a good way to fulfill the lab requirement for neuroscience, but I wish that the final research proposal assignment was incorporated more into the course itself. The last class period was the first time we talked about the 12 page final paper, which was a little jarring. I wish the last couple of assignments would have been focused on choosing topics and writing the first sections so that the amount of work required after the end of classes was  not as high. Additionally, I wish we spent more time learning about research methods outside of just IATs and fMRI.
The reaction papers were very clear in criteria and easy to follow and handle. I think the structure of the course was very well thought out and put together.

Very low-key, no pressure environment, which is quite extraordinary to have at Yale! I appreciated this aspect the most.
Very clear structure of lectures throughout the semester, made it easy to follow. 
Super cool projects (building electric hand, clay brain, prism goggles, ...) in class to get first-hand experience in research methods. Definitely consolidated my knowledge.

Strengths: The course was structured to provide students with numerous opportunities to practice the material we learn in class. The workload was perfect - not so little that course content went in one ear and out the other, and not so much that it became a burden. Furthermore, feedback was timely and instructive.

Weaknesses: The course faces the challenge of being attended by students with diverse backgrounds in psychological and neuroscientific methods. As it stands, I had to wait until about halfway through the semester before starting to learn anything.
Overall great course
Strengths: Professor, hands-on approach, creative lectures/interesting content

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely! The course is interesting, easy, and useful- what else could you ask for?
Yes! It's just a great form of learning without pressure exactly what you need to know for writing scientific papers/be in science, even if it's just for the Bachelor's thesis.
Definitely!

If you're taking it with Professor Lazzaro, I would highly recommend this course regardless of what your major is. 

If you're looking to get into cognitive neuroscience, this course is an absolute must. Even if you're not, I would highly recommend taking it just to gain a greater appreciation of related methods so that you can become a more informed consumer of such research. Also, it only meets once a week, so that's nice.

YES! This course taught me a lot about scientific writing and the various methodologies open to neuroscientists and psychologists. The professor and TF were always available and willing to talk about my career beyond the class. Overall a great entry point into the world of fMRI, neuroscience and writing scientific papers
Yes. Very good course.
Yes, especially if you're a neuroscience major looking to fulfill their neuroscience lab credit. It's a full credit, and the Professor is incredibly kind.
